content.question: A block on a horizontal surface is attached to one end of a spring and the other end of the spring is attached to a fixed wall, as shown in the figure. The block is initially held in place with its center at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>. It is then released from rest and oscillates between points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>. The block-spring system is in equilibrium when the center of the block is at Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, located halfway between points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>. Later, the spring is replaced with a second spring of the same length but with a larger spring constant. This time the block is released from rest with its center to the left of Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>. Where is the center of the block relative to Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> when the new block-spring system is at equilibrium?

choices.label: To the left of Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>
To the right of Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>
The new equilibrium position cannot be determined without more information about how much the spring constant and initial spring compression were changed.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
